message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The specific weakness during internal rotation against resistance suggests an injury to the subscapularis muscle. All other options would show weakness in different actions and against different resistance.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the injury and weakness on internal rotation against resistance points to injury of the subscapularis muscle. Supraspinatus muscle injury would result in weakness with abduction against resistance, deltoid injury with weakness in abduction, and infraspinatus with weakness in external rotation against resistance.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the injury and the weakness with internal rotation against resistance is classic for subscapularis muscle injury. None of the other options would result in weakness with internal rotation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The injury happened when the arm was outstretched, which suggests strain on the subscapularis muscle that attaches to the lesser tuberosity of the humerus. Weakness in internal rotation is also a sign of subscapularis muscle injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the injury and weakness during internal rotation suggest injury to the subscapularis muscle. Supraspinatus is responsible for abduction, Deltoid for shoulder flexion and extension, and Infraspinatus for external rotation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The injury and weakness during internal rotation of the arm against resistance suggest a rotator cuff injury. Among the options, only Subscapularis muscle is responsible for internal rotation of the arm and is a part of the rotator cuff.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The injury and weakness on internal rotation suggest a rotator cuff injury, specifically to the subscapularis muscle. Among the options, subscapularis muscle is the only rotator cuff muscle that primarily functions as an internal rotator of the shoulder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The posterior part of the outstretched arm and weakness with internal rotation against resistance suggest an injury to the subscapularis muscle. None of the other options would cause weakness with this specific movement.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The specific weakness on internal rotation against resistance indicates injury to the subscapularis muscle. All other options would have different patterns of weakness or pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The posterior part of the outstretched arm is where subscapularis muscle is located, and weakness in internal rotation against resistance suggests injury to the muscle. None of the other options are associated with weakness in internal rotation.
